title-group.article-title: Endovascular Repair for Left Common Iliac Artery Occlusion Following Blunt Trauma Without Associated Bony Injury: Image in Vascular Surgery

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Vascular Surgery, Worcestershire Royal Hospital, West Midlands, UK
2Department of Radiology, Worcestershire Royal Hospital, West Midlands, UK

author-notes.corresp: Henrietta Poon, Department of Vascular Surgery, Worcestershire Royal Hospital, Charles Hastings Way, Newtown Road, Worcester WR5 1DD, UK. Email: hpoonie@doctors.net.uk

abstract.p: Common iliac artery injury (CIAI), commonly associated with pelvic fractures may present with a potentially fatal combination of haemorrhage and limb ischaemia. We report a case of isolated CIAI from blunt trauma without bony injury treated successfully using endovascular repair.

body.p: Common iliac artery injury (CIAI) from blunt trauma is rare due to its anatomical position within the protective pelvic girdle.1 It is often associated with a pelvic fracture or seatbelt injury and may present with a potentially fatal combination of hemorrhage and limb ischemia.2 We report a rare case of isolated CIAI from blunt trauma without bony injury treated successfully using endovascular repair. A 26-year-old factory worker sustained abdominal and lumbar spine compression in a metal press for 20 seconds. He presented to the emergency department with loss of sensation in the left leg and lower back and abdominal pain. He was hemodynamically stable and physical examination revealed bruising over the lumbar spine and anterior abdominal wall with reduction of power and sensory loss in the left leg which was cold and pale. No pulses were palpable below a weak left femoral. Computed tomographic (CT) imaging showed a retroperitoneal hematoma in the left psoas muscle with occlusion of the left common iliac artery (CIA; Figure 1). Further CT angiography in a regional vascular center confirmed a 2.5 cm occlusion of the middle third of the left CIA with preservation of the common iliac bifurcation and distal arterial tree. There was no evidence of active arterial bleeding or pseudoaneurysm formation (Figure 2).

caption.p: Retroperitoneal hematoma in left psoas muscles with occlusion of the left CIA seen on CT. CIA, common iliac artery; CT, computed tomography.
Three-dimensional CT angiogram reconstruction confirms occlusion of left CIA. CIA, common iliac artery; CT, computed tomography.

body.p: The patient underwent an emergency endovascular stenting procedure under general anesthesia. An Endurant (Medtronic) covered stent was deployed across the left common iliac artery and proximal external iliac artery using a dual common femoral artery approach (Figure 3). On-table angiography demonstrated good flow across the stented segment with no extravasation of contrast. The patient was discharged home on the third postoperative day. At 6-week review, the patient had made a full recovery with no residual arterial or neurological deficit and discharged from follow-up.

caption.p: Placement of Endurant stent across left CIA. CIA, common iliac artery.

body.p: Clinical manifestations of CIAI may be difficult to assess in patients with multiple distracting injuries. Other injuries such as transection of the abdominal musculature, bowel perforation, and seatbelt marking should alert clinicians toward a potential diagnosis of CIAI.3 Noncontrast CT scan may not reveal the extent of the vascular abnormality as demonstrated in this case. Computed tomography angiography provides an ideal noninvasive approach to imaging that is able to characterize the vascular abnormality and thereby guide treatment.4 Surgical repair is often difficult in the trauma setting where gaining adequate exposure with proximal and distal control of the vessel can be challenging. It may also require the use of prosthetic material in a contaminated field. The endovascular approach offers benefits in terms of easier access to the target lesion, reduction in blood transfusion requirement, and obviates the potential need for systemic heparinization.5 These advantages are particularly attractive in a trauma setting where the patient may have already sustained substantial blood loss.

We have described the successful use of endovascular stenting to treat a stable patient with isolated CIAI, an infrequent injury which may be overlooked and remain asymptomatic until arterial occlusion prevails resulting in permanent disability or limb loss. Consequently, it is important to have a high index of suspicion when such patients present with abnormal lower limb pulses despite the absence of skeletal injury.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
